   Assessment and Plan
 HYPERTENSION, MALIGNANT (HYPERTENSIVE CRISIS, HYPERTENSIVE EMERGENCY)
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:
   63-year-old male with DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma
   s/p chemotherapy (no radiation therapy),  s/p kidney transplant (on
   Rapamune & Prednisone) who presents with worsening HTN urgency and 2
   weeks of throbbing headaches and found to have extensive bihemispheric
   white matter lesions on MRI (R temporal and L parieto-occipital).
   .
   .
   #Headaches: Likely due to multiple lesions noted on brain MRI in
   conjunction with poorly controlled HTN. Based on Lesions on MRI most
   likely differential includes lymphoma, viral (toxoplasmosis), and PML.
   Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) also in the
   differential as well, although less likely. LP CSF with 2WBC, 1RBC, 85
   lymphocytes, 15 monos, elevated protein of 162, and normal glucose in
   the 70s which makes bacterial/fungal sources highly unlikely.
   .
   --f/up neurology recs
   --continue Tylenol
   --follow-up final MRI read
   --consider full NSG consult / ? biopsy for firm diagnosis
   --keep goal SBP between 130-160s on NTG drip
   --consider MR spectroscopy for further assessment of the lesions & felt
   he would likely need biopsy for firm diagnosis.
   .
   #HEME/Oncology: B-cell lymphoma diagnosed [**1-/2185**], patient is now s/p 6
   cycles of chemotherapy (R-[**Hospital1 **] x5, R-CHOP x1) and 2 cycles of IT ara-C
   with last dose given on [**2185-7-13**] per OMR. No radiation therapy. Patient
   had been on immunosuppression meds for many years for renal transplant
   which may have played role in malignancy risk. Followed here by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 6604**] & Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3337**]
   .
   --f/up final MRI read
   --collect chemistries/LDH/CBC with differential (unable to get labs in
   ED)
   --call formal Oncology consult and f/up Heme/Onc recs in a.m.
   --consider biopsy/NSG consult for tissue biopsy to confirm if mass is
   lymphoma--> d/w Heme/Onc
   --intracranial edema noted, will discuss mannitol and increase
   glucocorticoids with NSG/neuro
   .
   #Hypertension: In regards to his HTN, it appears his SBPs have been
   intermittently in the 170s over last month per OMR notes and his usual
   lisinopril and lasix have been discontinued for unclear reasons(likely
   related to his chemotherapies). Although not classical for PRES, given
   the possibility neurology team recommending goal SBP < 160 for tighter
   BP control. Of note, he also had borderline pulmonary artery systolic
   hypertension on [**5-/2185**] TTE.
   .
   --continue NTG gtt with goal SBPs 130s-160s range
   --continue usual carvedilol, clonidine
   --will consider diuresis with mannitol as above, or additional ACE or
   CCB as he is weaned off NTG if needed
   .
   #Renal transplant: His creatinine was 1.7 yesturday near usual baseline
   of 1.6-1.7 range. He is on sirolimus and prednisone for
   immunosuppression.
   .
   --consult renal transplant service
   --avoiding nephrotoxic medications
   --trend BUN/Cr
   --continue on Prednisone daily with Rapamune 2mg every other day
   --f/up sirolimus level
   .
   # Diabetes mellitus II: Etiology of his renal failure per OMR. Usually
   on home Lantus with humalog sliding scale. Followed by [**Hospital 294**] Clinic.
   .
   --continue home lantus dose ( need to verify w/wife -dose?)
   --[**Name2 (NI) **] fingersticks with SSI coverage for now
   --continue diabetic/cardiac diet
   .
   # Coronary artery disease: status-post 3V CABG in [**2173**]. No chest pain,
   EKG with no ischemic changes. He remains asymptomatic currently in
   [**Hospital Unit Name 10**]. Aspirin on hold due to IT chemotherapy per OMR.
   .
   --repeat EKG
   --continue carvedilol
   --holding ASA, statin for now
   .
   #Phantom limb pain: continue tylenol as needed, recently stopped taking
   Vicodin.
   .
   #GERD: continue protonix [**Hospital1 **]
   .
   #Access:  PIVs  x 2
   .
   #Full Code status, confirmed with patient
   .
   #Dispo - [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] while control BP and switch to PO medications, then
   consider transfer to OMED service
   .
   #Communication/social: [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) 7032**] [**Name (NI) 7033**] [**Name (NI) 2979**] #[**Telephone/Fax (1) 7034**]
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   22 Gauge - [**2185-8-10**] 06:22 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:
Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient's medical history, and current condition, there are several potential medical complications that can arise. These include:

1. Malignant hypertension: The patient has a history of hypertension and is currently experiencing worsening hypertension urgency. If left untreated or poorly controlled, this can lead to serious complications such as hypertensive encephalopathy, intracranial hemorrhage, or heart failure.

2. Bihemispheric white matter lesions: The presence of extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on the patient's brain MRI raises concerns for possible lymphoma, viral infection (such as toxoplasmosis), progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), or posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES). Further evaluation, such as a lumbar puncture (LP) and follow-up imaging studies, is needed to determine the underlying cause of these lesions.

3. Headaches: The patient has been experiencing worsening headaches, which are likely due to multiple lesions noted on the brain MRI and poorly controlled hypertension. It is important to closely monitor and manage the patient's pain and blood pressure to prevent further complications.

4. Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and has undergone 3-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) in 2013. Although currently asymptomatic, it is crucial to continue monitoring the patient's cardiac status, especially considering the use of chemotherapy

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and a history of non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He is currently admitted to the ICU due to hypertensive urgency, worsening headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI.

The potential medical complications that can arise from this case include:

1. Malignant hypertension (hypertensive crisis, hypertensive emergency): The patient's blood pressure has been intermittently in the 170s over the last month, indicating uncontrolled hypertension. This condition requires immediate medical attention to prevent end-organ damage.

2. Central nervous system involvement: The patient's symptoms, such as headaches and the presence of extensive white matter lesions on MRI, suggest central nervous system involvement. Differential diagnoses include lymphoma, viral (toxoplasmosis), and PML. Further evaluation, such as repeat MRI and CSF analysis, is necessary for a definitive diagnosis.

3. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES): Although less likely, PRES should be considered given the patient's poorly controlled hypertension and neurological symptoms. Immediate management of blood pressure and consideration of mannitol for intracranial edema may be required.

4. Renal transplant complications: The patient has a history of renal transplant and is on immunosuppressive medications. Monitoring renal function, avoiding nephro

1. Malignant hypertension (hypertensive crisis/hypertensive emergency): The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension, with intermittent SBPs in the 170s. 2. Biopsy of the left parietal lobe: The patient is scheduled for a biopsy with possible revascularization (REVD) planned for the next day. This procedure carries the risk of bleeding, infection, or complications related to anesthesia.

3. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES): Although less likely, the presence of extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI and poorly controlled hypertension raises the possibility of PRES. This neurological disorder requires close monitoring and management.

4. B-cell lymphoma: The patient has a history of B-cell lymphoma, which may have contributed to his renal failure. Further evaluation and follow-up with oncology services are recommended.

   63-year-old male with DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma
   s/p chemotherapy (no radiation therapy),  s/p kidney transplant (on
   Rapamune & Prednisone) who presents with worsening HTN urgency and 2
   weeks of throbbing headaches and found to have extensive bihemispheric
   white matter lesions on MRI (R temporal and L parieto-occipital).
   .
   .
   #Headaches: Likely due to multiple lesions noted on brain MRI in
   conjunction with poorly controlled HTN. Based on Lesions on MRI most
   likely differential includes lymphoma, viral (toxoplasmosis), and PML.
   Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES) also in the
   differential as well, although less likely. LP CSF with 2WBC, 1RBC, 85
   lymphocytes, 15 monos, elevated protein of 162, and normal glucose in
   the 70s which makes bacterial/fungal sources highly unlikely.
   .
   --f/up neurology recs
   --continue Tylenol
   --follow-up final MRI read
   --consider full NSG consult / ? biopsy for firm diagnosis
   --keep goal SBP between 130-160s on NTG drip
   --consider MR spectroscopy for further assessment of the lesions & felt
   he would likely need biopsy for firm diagnosis.
   .
   #HEME/Oncology: B-cell lymphoma diagnosed [**1-/2185**], patient is now s/p 6
   cycles of chemotherapy (R-[**Hospital1 **] x5, R-CHOP x1) and 2 cycles of IT ara-C
   with last dose given on [**2185-7-13**] per OMR. No radiation therapy. Patient
   had been on immunosuppression meds for many years for renal transplant
   which may have played role in malignancy risk. Followed here by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 6604**] & Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3337**]
   .
   --f/up final MRI read
   --collect chemistries/LDH/CBC with differential (unable to get labs in

   --call formal Oncology consult and f/up Heme/Onc recs in a.m.
   --consider biopsy/NSG consult for tissue biopsy to confirm if mass is
   lymphoma--> d/w Heme/Onc
   --intracranial edema noted, will discuss mannitol and increase
   glucocorticoids with NSG/neuro
   .
   #Hypertension: In regards to his HTN, it appears his SBPs have been
   intermittently in the 170s over last month per OMR notes and his usual
   lisinopril and lasix have been discontinued for unclear reasons(likely
   related to his chemotherapies). Although not classical for PRES, given
   the possibility neurology team recommending goal SBP < 160 for tighter
   BP control. Of note, he also had borderline pulmonary artery systolic
   hypertension on [**5-/2185**] TTE.
   .
   --continue NTG gtt with goal SBPs 130s-160s range
   --continue usual carvedilol, clonidine
   --will consider diuresis with mannitol as above, or additional ACE or
   CCB as he is weaned off NTG if needed
   .
   #Renal transplant: His creatinine was 1.7 yesturday near usual baseline
   of 1.6-1.7 range. He is on sirolimus and prednisone for
   immunosuppression.
   .
   --consult renal transplant service
   --avoiding nephrotoxic medications
   --trend BUN/Cr
   --continue on Prednisone daily with Rapamune 2mg every other day
   --f/up sirolimus level
   .

   .
   --continue home lantus dose ( need to verify w/wife -dose?)
   --[**Name2 (NI) **] fingersticks with SSI coverage for now
   --continue diabetic/cardiac diet
   .
   # Coronary artery disease: status-post 3V CABG in [**2173**]. No chest pain,
   EKG with no ischemic changes. He remains asymptomatic currently in
   [**Hospital Unit Name 10**]. Aspirin on hold due to IT chemotherapy per OMR.
   .
   --repeat EKG
   --continue carvedilol
   --holding ASA, statin for now
   .
   #Phantom limb pain: continue tylenol as needed, recently stopped taking
   Vicodin.
   .

   .

   .

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with multiple medical conditions including diabetes mellitus type II, coronary artery disease (status-post 3V CABG), chronic kidney disease (CKD), non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma, and a renal transplant. He presents with worsening hypertension urgency, headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI. The differential diagnosis includes lymphoma, viral (toxoplasmosis), and PML, as well as posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES).

The patient's current assessment and plan include:
- Hypertension, malignant (hypertensive crisis, hypertensive emergency): Goal SBP between 130-160s on NTG drip, consider full NSG consult/biopsy for firm diagnosis.
- Heme/Oncology: B-cell lymphoma diagnosed, patient s/p 6 cycles of chemotherapy, follow-up final MRI read, collect chemistries/LDH/CBC with differential, call formal Oncology consult and f/up Heme/Onc recs in a.m., consider biopsy/NSG consult for tissue biopsy to confirm if mass is lymphoma.
- Hypertension: Continue NTG gtt with goal SBPs 130s-160s range, continue usual carvedilol, clonidine, consider diuresis with mannitol as above, or additional ACE or CCB as he is weaned off NTG if needed.
- Renal transplant: Consult renal transplant service, avoid nephrotoxic medications, trend BUN/Cr, continue on Prednisone daily with Rapamune 2mg every other day, f/up sirolimus level.
- Diabetes mellitus II: Continue home Lantus dose (need to verify w/wife -dose?), [**Name2 (NI) **] fingersticks with SSI coverage for now, continue diabetic/cardiac diet.
- Coronary artery disease: Repeat EKG, continue carvedilol, holding ASA, statin for now.
- Phantom limb pain: Continue Tylenol as needed, recently stopped taking Vicodin.
- GERD: Continue protonix [**Hospital1 **].
- Access: PIVs x 2.
- Full Code status, confirmed with patient.
- Disposition - [**Hospital Unit Name 10**] while control BP and switch to PO medications, then consider transfer to OMED service.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Malignant hypertension leading to hypertensive encephalopathy, intracranial hemorrhage, or hypertensive heart failure.
2. Worsening of renal function due to hypertensive crisis or nephrotoxic medications.
3. Development of further neurological deficits or seizures due to the extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI.
4. Infection or bleeding complications from the planned neurosurgery or biopsy procedure.
5. Cardiac complications such as myocardial infarction or arrhythmias due to poorly controlled hypertension or discontinuation of aspirin and statin therapy.
6. Poor glycemic control leading to hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia.
7. Deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism due to immobilization and increased risk of clot formation.
8. Stress ulcer or gastrointestinal bleeding due to prolonged use of stress ulcer prophylaxis medications.
9. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged intubation and immobility.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is critically ill and currently admitted to the ICU. The patient has a history of hypertension, which is being treated with clonidine. There are concerns about intracranial abnormalities, specifically possible lymphoma, as indicated by new white matter lesions on the head MRI. However, there is no evidence of meningitis or encephalitis based on CSF analysis. The patient also has CNS abnormalities with predominately white matter abnormalities, and further CSF testing results are awaited. A recommendation for additional imaging, such as head MRI and head CT, has been made, along with a suggestion for a biopsy.

The patient has experienced ventricular ectopy, which is non-malignant, and it is being considered to resume a beta-blocker for improved control. The patient also has NIDDM (non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus) and will continue usual insulin therapy while monitoring glucose levels to maintain them below 150 mg/dL.

In terms of ICU care, the patient is receiving nutrition, glycemic control, and has multiple lines inserted. Prophylactic measures include stress ulcer prevention with an H2 blocker and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prevention with boots and systemic anticoagulation. The patient's head of bed (HOB) elevation is being used to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management of their various medical conditions.

He is currently receiving nitroprusside infusion for hypertension management and pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis.

The patient's assessment includes hypertension controlled with nitroprusside and planned conversion

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma.
- He presented with worsening HTN urgency and two weeks of throbbing headaches.
- Extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions were noted on an MRI, suggesting progression of his NHBCL.
- A biopsy from the CVVHD was concerning for tumor spread.
- The patient had a headache and cough, and his CVVHD clotted off.
- He is currently on CVVHD, and his creatinine was 1.7 yesterday.
- His SBPs have been intermittently in the 170s over the last month.
- The patient underwent kidney transplantation and is on immunosuppressive medications.
- He is scheduled to start methotrexate once urine alkalization is completed using CVVHD.
- The patient has a history of coronary artery disease and is status-post 3V CABG.
- He is also diagnosed with diabetes mellitus II and is on home Lantus with Humalog sliding scale.
- The patient's vital signs are stable, and he has a positive fluid balance.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Malignant hypertension due to uncontrolled blood pressure and the possibility of tumor spread.
2. Pulmonary edema due to fluid overload and new cough.
3. Clotting complications with CVVHD.
4. Infection

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He has undergone a kidney transplant and is on immunosuppressive medications. The patient presents with worsening hypertension urgency, two weeks of throbbing headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, suggestive of tumor spread from his non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. 

The patient's current medications include sirolimus, prednisone, labetalol, calcium gluconate, potassium chloride, pantoprazole, and an insulin regimen for his diabetes. He is also on CVVHD for renal support.

The patient's vital signs are relatively stable, with a blood pressure ranging from 112/46 mmHg to 172/65 mmHg, heart rate between 77 and 103 beats per minute, respiratory rate around 14-16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 94%. His temperature is within normal limits.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, while kidney function tests indicate impaired renal function. The urine analysis shows a specific gravity of 1.004, pH 6.5, and the presence of proteins and glucose.

The patient's physical examination reveals no signs of infection or distress. Neurological examination shows intact cranial nerves,

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a medical history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, renal transplant, and CNS lymphoma. He is currently admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and management of his conditions.

Key events and interventions include the placement of a dialysis catheter, initiation of continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVHD) with bicarbonate to alkalinize urine, and conversion to CRRT due to clotted CVVHD circuit and new-onset chills. The patient has been receiving labetalol infusion at 0.5 mg/min for blood pressure control and calcium gluconate at 1.4 grams/hour for CRRT.

Laboratory results show stable kidney function with a serum creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL, but elevated blood glucose levels ranging from 159 to 358 mg/dL. The patient's platelet count has been fluctuating between 70-97 thousand/mm3, and his white blood cell count has been within normal range.

Physical examination findings include stable vital signs with blood pressure ranging from 112/46 to 172/65 mmHg, heart rate between 77-103 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. The patient's temperature is within normal limits.

The patient is a 68-inch tall individual with an unknown weight, admitted to the ICU for hypertension, CNS abnormalities, and renal transplant. The patient has a history of diabetes, allergies to adhesive tape, and rashes. They are currently receiving multiple medications including labetalol, calcium gluconate (CRRT), and others. The patient's vital signs are within normal limits, except for a slightly low blood pressure. The patient's fluid balance shows a positive intake of 2,207 mL and output of 2,160 mL over the past 24 hours. The patient is receiving respiratory support with oxygen delivery but has an ABG indicating respiratory acidosis. The patient's labs show elevated levels of creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, glucose, and leukocyte count, along with low platelet count and hemoglobin. The patient's electrolytes are also abnormal, with high potassium, sodium, chloride, and bicarbonate levels. The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension, CNS abnormalities consistent with lymphoma, and renal transplant requiring dialysis post-MTX to avoid renal toxicity. The patient is being managed with dexamethasone, chemo decisions being made, and considering dialysis. The patient's NIDDM is being managed with usual insulin and monitoring glucose levels.

1. Hypotension due to overaggressive blood pressure control.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 68-inch male with a chief complaint of hypertension. The patient has been receiving dialysis since August 12th and has experienced several complications, including CVVHD clots, chills, and cough. The patient's vital signs are relatively stable, with a temperature of 36.9 C, heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 112/46 to 172/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 94% on 2LPM. The patient's heart rhythm is sinus rhythm. The patient has received multiple infusions of medications such as labetalol and calcium gluconate (CRRT). The patient's labs show elevated levels of WBC, Hct, and glucose, along with decreased levels of Plt and Cr. The patient has a history of renal transplant, hypertension, CNS lymphoma, NIDDM, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypertensive emergency or encephlopathy due to uncontrolled hypertension.
2. Infection or sepsis due to chills and cough, which could indicate a possible infection in the bloodstream or lungs.
3. Renal complications due to CVVHD clots, which may lead to further deterioration of renal function.
4. Thrombocytopenia, which could increase the risk of bleeding.
5. Hyperglycemia indicated by elevated glucose levels, requiring careful monitoring and management.

The patient is a 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of hypertension, CNS lymphoma, renal transplant, thrombocytopenia, and NIDDM. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.2°C (97.1°F), heart rate of 89 bpm, blood pressure of 112/46 mmHg, SpO2 of 94% on 2LPM, and sinus rhythm. The patient has extreme trace edema, and laboratory results show anemia, elevated creatinine, hyperglycemia, and thrombocytopenia. The patient is receiving CVVHD to avoid MTX renal toxicity and is on sirolimus and dexamethasone. The plan is to advance diet, maintain blood pressure control, start chemotherapy for CNS lymphoma, and monitor glucose levels.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is currently low, which may require further management and monitoring.
2. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections due to the use of CVVHD and indwelling lines.
3. Bleeding: Thrombocytopenia puts the patient at risk for bleeding complications.
4. Renal dysfunction: Elevated creatinine levels indicate potential renal dysfunction, which may require adjustment of medications and further management.
5. Hyperglycemia: The patient's high blood glucose levels need to be monitored and managed to prevent

   63-year-old male with DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma
   s/p chemotherapy (no radiation therapy), s/p kidney transplant (on
   Rapamune & Prednisone) who presents with worsening HTN urgency and 2
   weeks of throbbing headaches and found to have extensive bihemispheric
   white matter lesions on MRI (R temporal and L parieto-occipital), most
   likely representing progression of his NHBCL now s/p bx on CVVHD to
   initiate chemotherapy.
   #Headaches: Likely due to multiple lesions noted on brain MRI rather
   than poorly controlled HTN.  Biopsy is concerning for tumor spread. LP
   CSF with 2WBC, 1RBC, 85 lymphocytes, 15 monos, elevated protein of 162,
   glucose in the 70s.
   --f/up neurology recs
   --continue Tylenol PRN pain
   --f/u final results of brain biopsy
   --keep goal 130<SBP<160  per neurosurg recs
   --continue po labatelol and clonidine; off of labetolol gtt
   --d/c dexamethasone today
   #HEME/Oncology: B-cell lymphoma diagnosed [**1-/2185**], patient is now s/p 6
   cycles of chemotherapy (R-[**Hospital1 **] x5, R-CHOP x1) and 2 cycles of IT ara-C
   with last dose given on [**2185-7-13**] per OMR. No radiation therapy. Patient
   had been on immunosuppression meds for many years for renal transplant
   which may have played role in malignancy risk. Followed here by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 6604**] & Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3337**]
   -- methotrexate infusion yesterday after urine alkalization (pH < 7.5)
   completed using CVVHD
   --d/ced dexamethasone, restart prednisone
   --check sirolimus level [**8-15**] AM
   --discuss heparin SC tid for DVT prophylaxis
   --check methotrexate q 24 hrs
   --q 4 urine pH, adjust bicarb as indicated
   -- f/u with renal transplant service regarding length of CVVHD
   #Hypertension: In regards to his HTN, it appears his SBPs have been
   intermittently in the 170s over last month per OMR notes.  His usual
   lisinopril and lasix have been discontinued for unclear reasons (likely
   related to his chemotherapies). Of note, he also had borderline
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension on [**5-/2185**] TTE.  Pt arrived from
   the ED on nitro gtt.
   --labetolol gtt transitioned to PO equivalent with 130<SBP<160 per
   neurosurgery recs.
   --continue usual clonidine, hold carvedilol for now, plan to restart on
   D/C if indicated
   #Renal transplant: On CVVHD. His creatinine was 1.7 yesterday near
   usual baseline of 1.6-1.7 range. He is on sirolimus and prednisone for
   immunosuppression. On CVVHD, 1.6L positive in past 6 hours, now with
   new cough concerning for pulmonary edema [**3-14**] fluid overload.
   --Will continue with CVVHD, discuss with renal optimal length of
   treatment
   --switch from q4 to q 12 hr labs today, will confirm with renal
   --avoiding nephrotoxic medications
   --trend BUN/Cr
   --continue with Rapamune 2mg every other day
   --sirolumus level pending for [**8-15**]
   # Diabetes mellitus II: Etiology of his renal failure per OMR. Usually
   on home Lantus with humalog sliding scale. Followed by [**Hospital 294**] Clinic.
   --calculate new lantus dose based on 24 hour insulin usage ( 22 U
   glargine)
   --change accuchecks to q6h with sliding scale regular insulin
   increase by 2 units per increment.
   --continue diabetic/cardiac diet
   # Coronary artery disease: status-post 3V CABG in [**2173**]. No chest pain,
   EKG with no ischemic changes. He remains asymptomatic currently in
   [**Hospital Unit Name 10**]. Aspirin on hold due to IT chemotherapy per OMR.
   --hold carvedilol while pressures stable
   --continue PO labetalol, clonidine
   --holding ASA, statin for now
   #Phantom limb pain: continue tylenol as needed, recently stopped taking
   Vicodin.
   ICU Care

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He is currently in the ICU for worsening hypertension and two weeks of throbbing headaches. The patient has extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, which are most likely representing progression of his NHBCL. He underwent a brain biopsy, which is concerning for tumor spread. CSF analysis showed elevated protein and lymphocytes.

The patient has been on immunosuppression medications for many years due to a renal transplant, which may have played a role in the development of malignancy. He has been receiving chemotherapy (R-[Hospital1] x5, R-CHOP x1) and IT ara-C, with the last dose given on [**2185-7-13**]. No radiation therapy has been administered.

The patient's current medications include methotrexate, prednisone, sirolimus, dexamethasone (which has been discontinued), labetalol, clonidine, furosemide (Lasix), pantoprazole (Protonix), and heparin for DVT prophylaxis.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.4°C, heart rate of 86 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 112-143/46-74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. He is on CVVHD due to renal transplant and has a creatinine level of 1.7.

The patient's recent lab results show a WBC count of 15.1-17.2 K/uL, Hct of 27.0-28.4%, platelet count of 60-66 K/uL, Cr of 1.0-1.2 mg/dL, TCO2 of 27-31 mEq/L, glucose of 38-157 mg/dL, and elevated LDH of 294 IU/L. Other lab values include normal levels of ALT/AST, Alk Phos/T Bili, Albumin, Ca++, Mg++, and PO4.

The patient's medical plan includes continuing Tylenol PRN pain, following up with neurology recommendations, final results of brain biopsy, keeping the goal SBP between 130-160 per neurosurgery recommendations, continuing po labetalol and clonidine, discontinuing dexamethasone, checking sirolimus level, discussing heparin SC tid for DVT prophylaxis, checking methotrexate q 24 hrs, and adjusting bicarb as indicated.

The potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include hypertensive crisis, tumor spread, pulmonary edema, fluid overload, diabetic complications, coronary artery disease, and infection.

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He has undergone chemotherapy and kidney transplantation and is currently in the ICU for worsening hypertension and headaches. The patient's medical history includes extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, consistent with tumor spread. He has received 6 cycles of chemotherapy and 2 cycles of intrathecal ara-C. The patient is on immunosuppressive medications for his renal transplant and has a history of phantom limb pain.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Malignant hypertension: The patient's blood pressure has been intermittently in the 170s, indicating uncontrolled hypertension. This can lead to end-organ damage, such as stroke or heart attack.
2. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient is undergoing chemotherapy for lymphoma, which can cause tumor lysis syndrome. This condition occurs when cancer cells release their contents into the bloodstream, leading to electrolyte imbalances and kidney dysfunction.
3. Infection: Immunosuppression from chemotherapy and immunosuppressive medications can increase the risk of infection, including urinary tract infections, respiratory infections, and bloodstream infections.
4. Pulmonary edema: The patient's recent cough and fluid overload suggest the possibility of pulmonary edema, which can be caused by heart failure or fluid overload.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated

The patient is currently receiving various medications and treatments such as calcium gluconate, potassium chloride, acyclovir, pantoprazole, and others. They are also undergoing continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) and CVVHD to avoid methotrexate (MTX) renal toxicity.

2. CNS Lymphoma: The patient has been diagnosed with CNS lymphoma, which is a type of cancer that affects the brain and spinal cord. If left untreated or not managed effectively, it can cause further neurological symptoms and progression of the disease.
3. Renal Transplant: As the patient is a renal transplant recipient, they are at risk of complications related to the transplant itself, such as rejection or infection. Close monitoring and immunosuppressive therapy are necessary to prevent these complications.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low (60 K/uL), indicating thrombocytopenia. This condition

   63-year-old male with DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma
   s/p chemotherapy (no radiation therapy), s/p kidney transplant (on
   Rapamune & Prednisone) who presents with worsening HTN urgency and 2
   weeks of throbbing headaches and found to have extensive bihemispheric
   white matter lesions on MRI (R temporal and L parieto-occipital), most
   likely representing progression of his NHBCL now s/p bx on CVVHD to
   initiate chemotherapy.
   #Headaches: Likely due to multiple lesions noted on brain MRI rather
   than poorly controlled HTN.  Biopsy is concerning for tumor spread. LP
   CSF with 2WBC, 1RBC, 85 lymphocytes, 15 monos, elevated protein of 162,
   glucose in the 70s.
   --appreciate neurology/neurosurg recs
   --will discuss re-starting aspirin with neurosurg
   --continue Tylenol PRN pain
   --f/u final results of brain biopsy
   #HEME/Oncology: B-cell lymphoma diagnosed [**1-/2185**], patient is now s/p 6
   cycles of chemotherapy (R-[**Hospital1 **] x5, R-CHOP x1) and 2 cycles of IT ara-C
   with last dose given on [**2185-7-13**] per OMR. No radiation therapy. Patient
   had been on immunosuppression meds for many years for renal transplant
   which may have played role in malignancy risk. Followed here by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 6604**] & Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3337**]
   -- s/p methotrexate, continue to monitor urine pH (goal pH < 7.5)
   --d/ced dexamethasone, prednisone restarted
   --sirolimus level pending
   --check methotrexate q 24 hrs
   --q 4 urine pH, adjust bicarb as indicated
   -- f/u with renal transplant and BMT service regarding length of CVVHD
   #Hypertension: In regards to his HTN, it appears his SBPs have been
   intermittently in the 170s over last month per OMR notes.  His usual
   lisinopril and lasix have been discontinued for unclear reasons (likely
   related to his chemotherapies). Of note, he also had borderline
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension on [**5-/2185**] TTE.  Pt arrived from
   the ED on nitro gtt.
   --keep goal 130<SBP<160  per neurosurg recs
   --continue po labatelol and clonidine; off of labetolol gtt, will add
   hydralizine if BPs are not controlled, avoid gtt if possible
   #Renal transplant: On CVVHD for dialysis of methotrexate. His
   creatinine nl, good UOP. He is on sirolimus and prednisone for
   immunosuppression. Goal is fluid neutral per renal recs.  Unfortunately
   CVVHD has repeatedly clotted off.
   --Will continue with CVVHD, discuss with renal/BMT optimal length of
   treatment and possibility of switching to HD
   --switched from q4 to q 12 hr labs today, will confirm with renal
   --avoiding nephrotoxic medications
   --trend BUN/Cr

   --sirolumus level pending

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He is currently in the ICU for worsening hypertension and headaches. The patient underwent a kidney transplant in the past and is on immunosuppressive medications. He received chemotherapy for his lymphoma but experienced complications leading to his current condition.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypertensive crisis: The patient has high blood pressure readings ranging from 170s over the last month, indicating possible malignant hypertension. This requires immediate medical attention to prevent end-organ damage.

2. White matter lesions on MRI: The presence of extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on the brain MRI suggests possible tumor spread or other neurological conditions. Further evaluation and management are necessary to determine the cause and appropriate treatment.

3. CVVHD complications: The patient is on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVHD) for methotrexate removal. However, the CVVHD has repeatedly clotted off, which can lead to inadequate fluid removal and electrolyte imbalances. Close monitoring and adjustments in the treatment are required.

4. Renal function: The patient's renal function needs to be closely monitored due to his history of chronic kidney disease, recent chemotherapy, and ongoing CVVHD. Changes in creatinine levels and urine output should be evaluated to ensure proper kidney function.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus II, hypertension, coronary artery disease (status-post 3V CABG), chronic kidney disease (CKD), non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma (NHBCL) post-chemotherapy, and renal transplant. He presents with worsening hypertension urgency, headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, most likely representing progression of his NHBCL.

The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVHD) due to renal failure. His blood pressure has been intermittently in the 170s over the last month, and his usual medications for hypertension (lisinopril and lasix) have been discontinued. He is also experiencing headaches and has a history of malignant hypertension.

Additionally, the patient has a history of coronary artery disease and had undergone 3-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) in 2013. He is currently asymptomatic with no chest pain or ischemic changes on EKG.

The patient also has a diagnosis of non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma, for which he has received 6 cycles of chemotherapy and 2 cycles of intrathecal ara-C. His immunosuppression medications for renal transplant may have played a role in the development of malignancy risk.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 71 bpm, blood pressure of 174/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths/min, and oxygen saturation of 100% on nasal cannula. His general appearance is pleasant, well appearing, and in no acute distress. His neurological examination is essentially unremarkable, except for occasional confusion and disorientation.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine, and glucose levels are within normal limits. The PT/PTT/INR levels are slightly elevated, while the rest of the lab values are within normal range.

The patient's plan of care includes continuing Tylenol for headaches, following up with neurology recommendations, final results of brain biopsy, and keeping systolic blood pressure goal between 130-160 per neurosurgery recommendations. He will continue with po labetalol and clonidine, and off of labetolol gtt. Dexamethasone will be discontinued today. The patient's immunosuppression medications (sirolimus and prednisone) will be continued.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this patient include:

1. Hypertensive crisis: The patient's intermittent blood pressure readings in the 170s indicate uncontrolled hypertension, which can lead to hypertensive crisis if not managed properly.
2. Renal failure: The patient is currently on CVVHD due to renal failure. There

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He is currently in the ICU due to worsening hypertension and headaches. The patient has been diagnosed with extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, most likely representing progression of his non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. 

The patient's current medications include sirolimus, prednisone, leucovorin, and various other medications for his medical conditions. He is also on CVVHD for dialysis of methotrexate. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he has been experiencing neck pain overnight, which is concerning for possible infection or abscess. 

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low platelet count, and elevated levels of creatinine and blood urea nitrogen. His electrolytes are within normal range, and his glucose level is low. 

The patient's current plan includes continuing CVVHD until methotrexate level is less than 0.05, monitoring urine pH and adjusting bicarb as necessary, checking methotrexate levels every 24 hours, and continuing prednisone. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and neck pain could indicate an underlying infection, which may require further investigation and treatment.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions and treatments. These include:

1. Infection: The presence of fever and positive urine culture for Enterococci suggests a possible urinary tract infection. The patient's immunocompromised state due to chemotherapy and immunosuppressive medications increases the risk of infections.

2. Hypertensive crisis: The patient has a history of hypertension and intermittent blood pressures in the 170s. Discontinuation of antihypertensive medications (lisinopril and lasix) may contribute to this condition. The elevated pulmonary artery systolic hypertension on TTE also indicates potential cardiac involvement.

3. Malignant hypertension emergency: Given the patient's severe hypertension and symptoms like headache, there is a concern for malignant hypertension, which can lead to end-organ damage.

4. CNS involvement: The extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI and the worsening headaches raise concerns about central nervous system (CNS) involvement, potentially due to tumor spread or other causes.

5. Kidney dysfunction: The patient's history of chronic kidney disease (CKD) and being on dialysis suggests ongoing kidney dysfunction. The clotted CVVHD and fluctuating creatinine levels indicate challenges in maintaining adequate fluid balance and managing methotrexate levels.

6. Cardiovascular disease: The patient's history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous CABG surgery puts him at risk for cardiovascular complications

The patient has been on immunosuppression medications for his renal transplant, which may have played a role in the development of malignancy. He has completed 6 cycles of chemotherapy and 2 cycles of intrathecal (IT) ara-C. His methotrexate level was below 0.05, leading to the discontinuation of CVVHD. He also has new enterococcus in his urine and consolidations on CXR, which are concerning for edema, infection, or methotrexate toxicity. The patient is currently on sirolimus and prednisone for immunosuppression, and his creatinine is within normal limits with good urine output.

1. Infection: The patient has a new enterococcus infection in his urine and consolidations on CXR, indicating a possible infection. It is crucial to treat the UTI promptly and monitor for any signs of systemic infection.

The patient's lab results indicate leukocytosis with a WBC count of 14.1, slightly decreased platelet count of 52, and normal hemoglobin level of 7.9 g/dL. Other lab values are within normal limits.

   Rapamune & Prednisone) who presents with worsening HTN urgency and 2
   weeks of throbbing headaches and found to have extensive bihemispheric
   white matter lesions on MRI (R temporal and L parieto-occipital), most
   likely representing progression of his NHBCL now s/p bx on CVVHD to
   initiate chemotherapy.
   #HEME/Oncology: B-cell lymphoma diagnosed [**1-/2185**], patient is now s/p 6
   cycles of chemotherapy (R-[**Hospital1 **] x5, R-CHOP x1) and 2 cycles of IT ara-C
   with last dose given on [**2185-7-13**] per OMR. No radiation therapy. Patient
   had been on immunosuppression meds for many years for renal transplant
   which may have played role in malignancy risk. Followed here by Dr.
   [**Last Name (STitle) 6604**] & Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 3337**].  Will plan to continue CVVHD until methotrexate
   level is <0.05
   -- s/p methotrexate, continue to monitor urine pH (goal pH < 7.5) and
   adjust bicarb as necessary
   --continue prednisone
   --sirolimus level low at 3.6, pharmacy to redose
   --check methotrexate q 24 hrs
   --q 4 urine pH, adjust bicarb as indicated
   --continue leucovorin for total 12 doses
   .
   #Neck pain: Patient with new neck pain overnight in the paraspinous
   region.  Neck plain films were unremarkable.  Concern for MS [**First Name (Titles) **] [**Last Name (Titles) **]
   infectious process, however pt does not have markedly increased temp or
   WBC.  Less concerned for meningitis given physical exam.  Pt does have
   dialysis catheter in place which could be contributing to his pain as
   well.  MRI of the neck would be helpful to assess for abcess however
   this is difficult while pt is on CVVHD.
   -continue to follow WBC, fever curve
   -will discuss with neurosurg
   -MRI if pt still symptomatic after CVVHD complete
   -benzos, oxycodone for pain
   .
   #Headaches: Likely due to multiple lesions noted on brain MRI rather
   than poorly controlled HTN.  Biopsy is concerning for tumor spread. LP
   CSF with 2WBC, 1RBC, 85 lymphocytes, 15 monos, elevated protein of 162,
   glucose in the 70s.
   --appreciate neurology/neurosurg recs
   --continue Tylenol PRN pain
   --f/u final results of brain biopsy
   .
   #Hypertension: In regards to his HTN, it appears his SBPs have been
   intermittently in the 170s over last month per OMR notes.  His usual
   lisinopril and lasix have been discontinued for unclear reasons (likely
   related to his chemotherapies). Of note, he also had borderline
   pulmonary artery systolic hypertension on [**5-/2185**] TTE.  Pt arrived from
   the ED on nitro gtt.
   --keep goal 130<SBP<160  per neurosurg recs
   --continue po labatelol and clonidine; off of labetolol gtt, will add
   hydralizine if BPs are not controlled, avoid gtt if possible
   #Renal transplant: On CVVHD for dialysis of methotrexate. His
   creatinine nl, good UOP. He is on sirolimus and prednisone for
   immunosuppression. Goal is fluid neutral per renal recs.  Unfortunately
   CVVHD has repeatedly clotted off.
   --Will continue with CVVHD until methotrexate level is <0.05
   --q6 labs
   --avoiding nephrotoxic medications
   --trend BUN/Cr
   --pharmacy to redose Rapamycin
   # Diabetes mellitus II: Etiology of his renal failure per OMR. Usually

   --minimal insulin requirements o/n, will follow and increase standing

   --continue ISS
   --continue diabetic/cardiac diet
   # Coronary artery disease: status-post 3V CABG in [**2173**]. No chest pain,

   [**Hospital Unit Name 10**]. Aspirin on hold due to IT chemotherapy per OMR.
   --continue PO labetalol, clonidine, add hydralizine if pressures remain
   poorly controled
   --holding ASA, statin for now.
   #Phantom limb pain: continue tylenol as needed, recently stopped taking

- The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma (NHL), and kidney transplant.
- He presents with worsening HTN urgency, throbbing headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, indicating possible progression of NHL.
- The patient is currently undergoing chemotherapy and has completed six cycles of R-CHOP and two cycles of IT ara-C.
- He is also on immunosuppression medications for his renal transplant, which may have contributed to the development of malignancy.
- The patient's neck pain overnight is concerning for MS or an infectious process, but further evaluation is needed due to the presence of a dialysis catheter.
- His headaches are likely due to multiple lesions noted on brain MRI, rather than poorly controlled HTN.
- A lumbar puncture (LP) shows elevated protein and lymphocytes in the CSF, suggesting tumor spread.
- The patient's blood pressure has been intermittently in the 170s over the last month, and his usual medications have been discontinued.
- He also has borderline pulmonary artery systolic hypertension on TTE.
- The patient's renal function is stable with good urine output and normal creatinine levels.
- He is on sirolimus and prednisone for immunosuppression and is undergoing CVVHD for dialysis of methotrexate.
- The patient

He presents with worsening hypertension urgency, two weeks of throbbing headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, most likely representing progression of his non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma now treated with biopsy and methotrexate chemotherapy.

The patient is currently in the ICU and has several medical complications. He has a fever and elevated WBC count, indicating a possible infection. He also has thrombocytopenia, which could be due to chemotherapy or serolimus. His anemia is likely secondary to chronic disease. The patient's neck pain has resolved, likely due to multiple lesions on brain MRI rather than poorly controlled hypertension. His headaches have improved, but a brain biopsy is concerning for tumor spread. His hypertension is poorly controlled, with intermittent SBPs in the 170s over the last month. He has been off his usual lisinopril and lasix for unclear reasons.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He underwent a kidney transplant and has been on immunosuppression medication. The patient presented with worsening hypertension, headaches, and was found to have extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, indicating progression of his non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma. He has been receiving chemotherapy but continues to experience complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Infection: The patient has a history of urinary tract infections and enterococcus in the urine. He is also febrile, which may indicate an ongoing infection.
2. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a low platelet count, which could be due to chemotherapy or immunosuppression. This increases the risk of bleeding.
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease and received a blood transfusion. Close monitoring of hematocrit levels is necessary.
4. Headaches: The patient's headaches have improved but may recur due to the multiple lesions noted on brain MRI.
5. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is difficult to control, and he requires multiple medications to manage his hypertension.
6. Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is rising, indicating possible decline in renal function. Close monitoring of renal parameters is necessary.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of DM-II, HTN, CAD, CKD, and non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma (NHL) status post chemotherapy and kidney transplant.
- He presents with worsening HTN urgency, two weeks of throbbing headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, likely representing progression of his NHL.
- He has been on immunosuppressive medications for his renal transplant, which may have increased his risk for malignancy.
- The patient's neck pain has resolved, likely due to MS.
- His headaches have improved, possibly due to multiple lesions on brain MRI rather than poorly controlled HTN.
- A biopsy is concerning for tumor spread, and the patient will undergo further evaluation.
- He has thrombocytopenia, which could be caused by chemotherapy or sirolimus.
- His creatinine level is rising, but considering he was on methotrexate, it is expected to return to baseline.
- He has anemia of chronic disease and received 1 unit of PRBCs last night, with a stable hematocrit.
- He has a history of coronary artery disease and had a CABG in 2013. No chest pain, EKG with no ischemic changes.
- He also has phantom limb pain.
- The patient is on multiple medications, including flagyl for C. diff, famotidine, and other ICU medications.

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, coronary artery disease, chronic kidney disease, and non-Hodgkin's B-cell lymphoma status post chemotherapy and kidney transplant. The patient presents with worsening hypertension urgency, throbbing headaches, and extensive bihemispheric white matter lesions on MRI, likely representing progression of his NHL. 

The patient has been experiencing fever, elevated WBC count, and positive C. difficile toxin. He also has thrombocytopenia due to chemotherapy, but it could be caused by sirolimus as well. The patient's neck pain has resolved, likely due to MS origin. His hypertension is being managed with carvedilol and clonidine. The patient's renal function is stable, and he is on sirolimus and prednisone for immunosuppression. He has diabetes mellitus type II and coronary artery disease. 

The patient has been experiencing phantom limb pain and has been given Tylenol as needed. He is currently in the ICU and is stable, ready for transfer to the floor.
